properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Potential Winter Storm This Weekend. Total snowfall: possibly 15 cm. Maximum wind gusts: 50 to 80 km/h possible. Locations: Queens and Kings Counties. Time span: beginning Saturday evening and ending near noon Sunday. Remarks: A developing storm will likely affect eastern and central Prince Edward Island with snow and strong northeasterly winds Saturday night and Sunday morning. At this time, the amount of snowfall accumulation is very uncertain. Additional information will be provided as the details become more certain. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to PEstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #PEStorm.
Expires: 2020-02-01T01:06:13-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-31T09:07:13-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2211336017.2020
Area: Kings County P.E.I., Queens County P.E.I.
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong wind gusts, up to 90 km/h, are forecast to diminish by Friday morning. However, they may increase again Friday afternoon. ### Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.

properties.Title: Freezing Drizzle Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Areas of freezing drizzle have developed over the regions tonight and will continue into the overnight and Friday morning. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Freezing drizzle advisories are issued when drizzle falling in sub-zero temperatures is expected to freeze on contact, and over time create icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-31T16:32:56-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snow and wind expected. Total snowfall: 10 to 20 cm with locally higher amounts likely. Maximum wind gusts: near 80 km/h . Locations: western, northern, central, and northeastern Newfoundland. Time span: Sunday morning through to Monday morning. Remarks: Snow is expected to begin Sunday morning, and then transition briefly through rain or drizzle east of Deer Lake Sunday night. There is some uncertainty regarding the location of the highest snowfall accumulations and the public is advised to monitor future forecasts. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-02-01T00:43:22-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-31T08:44:22-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3185164058.2020

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Potential significant snowfall and wind expected. Total snowfall: 15 cm or more. Maximum wind gusts: 80 km/h with possibly gusts to 100 km/h. Locations: southeastern coastal Labrador. Time span: Sunday night through to overnight Monday. Remarks: Snow, strong northerly winds, and blowing snow are expected to develop Sunday night. Snow is expected to diminish to flurries late on Monday but the strong winds will likely continue into Tuesday. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-02-01T01:16:07-00:00

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snow, rain, and wind is expected. Total snowfall: 10 to 15 cm. Total rainfall: 15 to 25 mm. Locally higher amounts possible. Maximum wind gusts: 80 km/h except locally 100 km/h. Locations: southern and eastern Newfoundland. Time span: Sunday morning through to Monday morning. Remarks: Snow is expected to begin Sunday morning before changing to rain Sunday afternoon. Strong southeasterly winds will also develop Sunday. Rain combined with mild temperatures has the potential to cause localized flooding, especially given the large existing snow pack. There is still some uncertainty regarding total precipitation amounts and the public is advised to monitor future forecasts. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-02-01T00:45:59-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-31T08:46:59-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3664874068.2020

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. An intense low pressure system will bring southwest winds of 80 km/h to the west coast of Vancouver Island late this afternoon and this evening. Winds will ease to 40 to 60 km/h late this evening in the wake of the low. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. High winds may toss loose objects or cause tree branches to break. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-02-01T04:29:43-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-31T12:30:43-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2951666122.2020
Area: West Vancouver Island
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Damaging westerly wind gusts near 120 km/h will diminish later this morning, however, wind speeds will increase again starting late this afternoon. A few weather stations in extreme southwestern Alberta reported gusts as high as 161 km/h through the night. Tonight wind gusts in some areas are expected to be at least that severe again. Vehicles in these areas are at high risk of being overturned or experience loss of control, especially along exposed roads. Winds gusting over 100 km/h are forecast to occur into Saturday. ### Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.
Expires: 2020-02-01T04:08:18-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-31T12:09:18-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1776860960.2020

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Potential winter storm this weekend. Total snowfall: potentially 15 cm or more. Maximum wind gusts: 50 to 80 km/h possible. Locations: most of Nova Scotia. Time span: Saturday afternoon into Sunday. Remarks: A developing storm may affect the Maritime Provinces this weekend. There is a very high degree of uncertainty with this storm since its track remains uncertain. The potential exists for strong winds accompanied by significant amounts of snow over much of the province, and possibly some rain over southern and eastern regions. Additional information will be provided as the details become more certain. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, at times heavy, continues. An intense low pressure system with subtropical moisture will bring heavy rain to the Fraser Valley, Howe Sound, Gibsons and Metro Vancouver today through to Saturday. The warm front associated with this system moved through the area last night bringing rain, at times heavy. For Metro Vancouver, Bowen Island and Gibsons, there will be a break this afternoon as the warm front lifts north towards Squamish. The cold front associated with this system will return tonight with another round of heavy rain that will last through to Saturday midday. Total rainfall amounts for these events will be near 60 to 120 mm for the Fraser Valley, 130 mm for Howe Sound, 90 mm for Gibsons and 100 to 120 mm for parts of Metro Vancouver. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-02-01T02:37:00-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-31T10:38:00-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0311581124.2020
Area: Sunshine Coast - Gibsons to Earls Cove, Howe Sound, Metro Vancouver - North Shore including West Vancouver and North Vancouver, Metro Vancouver - central including the City of Vancouver Burnaby and New Westminster, Metro Vancouver - northeast including Coquitlam and Maple Ridge, Metro Vancouver - southeast including Surrey and Langley, Metro Vancouver - southwest including Richmond and Delta, Fraser Valley - west including Abbotsford, Fraser Valley - central including Chilliwack, Fraser Valley - east including Hope
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, at times heavy, is expected. An intense low pressure system with subtropical moisture will bring heavy rain to the Fraser Valley, Howe Sound, Gibsons and parts of Metro Vancouver tonight through to Saturday. The warm front associated with this system will move through the area tonight bringing rain, at times heavy. For Metro Vancouver, Bowen Island and Gibsons, there will be a break Friday afternoon as the warm front lifts north towards Squamish. The cold front associated with this system will return Friday night with another round of heavy rain that will last through to Saturday midday. Total rainfall amounts for these events will be near 60 to 120 mm for the Fraser Valley, 130 mm for Howe Sound, 80 mm for Gibsons and up to 100 mm for parts of Metro Vancouver. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. properties.Title: Smog Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: High concentration of pollutants are expected and will result in poor air quality, especially in urban areas where pollutant emissions are higher. High concentrations of pollutants should persist through late this morning. Late this morning. Meanwhile, air quality could deteriorate again this evening. ### Smog especially affects asthmatic children and people with respiratory ailments or heart disease. It is therefore recommended that these individuals avoid intense physical activity outdoors until the smog warning is lifted. In Quebec, wood heating is the main source of fine particles that contribute to smog during winter. This activity generates the largest number of these particulates, more than industrial activities and transportation. Additional information: To learn more about the Info-Smog program, go to Environment Canada’s website at www.canada.ca/info-smog-program. For air quality indexes in Quebec, visit the website of the Ministère de l'Environnement et de la Lutte contre les changements climatiques at www.iqa.environnement.gouv.qc.ca/contenu/index_en.asp. For the air quality index in Montréal, visit the Réseau de surveillance de la qualité de l’air de la Ville de Montréal’s website at www.rsqa.qc.ca (french only). To learn more about the effects of smog on your health in Québec, visit the Ministère de la Santé et des Services sociaux’s website at www.quebec.ca/en/health. You can also visit the Direction régionale de santé publique du CIUSSS du Centre-Sud-de-l’Île-de-Montréal at www.santemontreal.qc.ca/en/public. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2020-02-01T17:02:08-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, the Ministère de l'Environnement et de la Lutte contre les changements climatiques, the Ministère de la Santé et des Services sociaux, the Direction régionale de santé publique du CIUSSS du Centre-Sud-de-l’Île-de-Montréal, the City of Montréal, 2020-01-31T12:28:08-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3001109310.2020

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 15 to 25 cm is expected. A Pacific frontal system will continue to give snow heavy at times to Rogers Pass today. The snow will become mixed with rain late this afternoon as snow levels rise. Total snow accumulations up to 25 cm can be expected before the snow completely changes to rain this evening. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-02-01T04:29:03-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-31T12:30:03-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0965517528.2020
Area: Trans-Canada Highway - Eagle Pass to Rogers Pass

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected along the Icefields Parkway. A long duration heavy snowfall event will begin this evening and end Saturday evening. Total snowfall amounts will be between 30 and 50 cm, with locally upwards of 70 cm possible. Strong winds will accompany the snow, which will cause reduced visibility in blowing snow, especially over exposed areas. ### Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Very gusty winds expected in the Fraser Canyon today. A strong storm system will affect southwestern BC today. Extremely strong winds aloft will lead to a steep pressure gradient along the Fraser Canyon. Southerly winds are expected to increase this morning with gusts of 90 km/h possible at times from midday through at least this evening. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
